thread.title: 13 new laws and rules coming into force in 2019 and how they will affect you

author: Hannah Graham
title: 13 new laws and rules coming into force in 2019 and how they will affect you
text:
13 new laws and rules coming into force in 2019 and how they will affect you They include an increase in the National Minimum Wage and a rise in the personal tax threshold Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
The new year will bring plenty of changes - including alterations to UK law.
And some of the new regulations set to come into force in 2019 could have a big impact on your pocket.
Whether it's pension changes, tax adjustments or workers' rights rules, we've rounded up 22 of the new laws or rules that will make a difference to our readers' lives.
We've included a few upcoming legal decisions, expected to be made next year, which could affect workers in various fields, as well as changes to reporting and records which could make a difference to business owners.
Of course, there are likely to be plenty more legislative changes unveiled as the year goes on (the imminent Brexit, of course, being one of the factors making it impossible to predict exactly what Government announcements 2019 might bring.)
But for now, here are a few of the changes we know are coming: Increase in National Minimum Wage rates Money (Image: PA)
Both the National Living Wage (NLW) and National Minimum Wage (NMW) rates will increase in April 2019.
The “living wage”, the effective minimum wage for people aged 25 or over, will rise to £8.21 next April, up from £7.38 an hour now. Read More Warning over thousands of fake counterfeit goods and clothes - and how to spot them Tax changes for those on low salaries - and the well-paid
The income tax threshold will increase to £12,500 in April 2019. In other words, you won’t pay any income tax at all until you earn this much.
Assuming you have an annual income of at least £12,500, you’ll probably pay £130 less tax a year.
And the threshold for the higher rate of income tax - the 40% rate - will increase to £50,000-a-year.
It means that some people on higher salaries (more than £46,351-a-year) will also gain.
What does that mean? “A £130 a year gain for anyone earning over £12,500,” said Money Saving Expert's Martin Lewis.
There will also be more cash for the better off – with the point you start paying 40% income tax moving from £46,350 to £50,000.
“Which means another £730 in the pay packets of people who are above £50,000,” Martin added.
However, the super-rich won't get the full benefit – for once – with people making more than £100,000 not benefiting as much or even at all. Supermarket equal pay claims
Decisions on separate tribunal cases on the issue of equal pay involving Tesco, Asda, Morrisons and Sainsbury’s are expected in 2019.
It involves female shop workers who feel they are paid less than their male warehouse workers, despite carrying out a similar role. The decisions made could impact on other workers in future. National Minimum Wage for sleep-ins
The Court of Appeal says people working sleep-in shifts, such as nurses and care workers, are not entitled to the National Minimum Wage for time spent asleep where they were ‘available for work’ and not ‘actually working’.
A request to appeal this decision was lodged with the Supreme Court by Unison and a decision is expected in 2019. Settled status for EU nationals A European Union flag in front of Elizabeth Tower. (Image: Daniel Leal-Olivas/PA Wire)
European workers living in the UK can apply for settled status in 2019, allowing them to remain indefinitely after the end of the Brexit transition period in 2021.
To be granted settled status individuals must prove they have been living in the UK for five years by the date of application. Read More
